segments.content: This paper aims to develop a framework for measuring and valuing outcomes of programs and policies to protect the health and productivity of the economically active population, considering the challenges of scarce resources and demographic changes, with a focus on productivity-adjusted life years (PALYs) as an alternative to quality-adjusted life years (QALYs), acknowledging the complex relationship between health and productivity and the potential for positive or negative correlations depending on the viewpoint.

The productivity indicator, which measures productivity and societal contributions in a broad sense, can be used to evaluate hypothetical distributions involving individuals experiencing varying degrees of health and productivity, with the social planner considering the QALY evaluation function and axioms of productivity independence, health independence, and time invariance at common health and full productivity, without considering individual total lifetime; this allows for relative evaluation of the distributions using various evaluation functions.

The segment discusses evaluating distributions using the productivity-and-quality-adjusted life years (PQALY) function, which considers the trade-offs between health, productivity, and lifespan, and demonstrates how to characterize natural compromises between these evaluation functions by strengthening the time and productivity independence axioms, resulting in the Theorem 5 stating that the PQALY evaluation function is equivalent to the stated conditions.

segments.header: satisfies COMMON, TICHP, PICHT, and TIUP.
segments.content: A social planner, using the QALY-PQALY evaluation function, considers both health effects and productivity effects as important outcomes of interventions, with the value of relative importance determined by the parameter δ, and adheres to the axioms of invariance between different effect components to ensure the desirability of interventions remains unchanged when lifetime among unproductive individuals following an intervention leads to extra life years or improved productivity, resulting in the QALY-PQALY evaluation function (Theorem 8) or the HPYE evaluation function (Theorem 9), which evaluates distributions by means of a convex combination of the QALYs and PQALYs, considering both health and productivity effects, and assigning equal weight to individuals with full health and maximal productivity.

The segment discusses how the choice of evaluation function in economic evaluations of health care or working environment interventions is guided by axioms, and how the selection of an appropriate evaluation function is crucial in determining the rank of different distributions, ultimately supporting the use of the QALY-PALY method when a majority is indifferent between adding productivity to one type or another, as indicated by the person trade-off technique, which allows for the creation of a flexible evaluation function.

The segment discusses a framework that classifies models as prioritarian evaluation functions, which rank well-being vectors according to the sum of a strictly increasing equivalent health-adjusted lifespan, sensitive to inequality in age-specific health and health-adjusted lifespan, and can be expanded to accommodate more general evaluations, considering two instantaneous attributes and a duration for individuals in a population distribution, while also allowing for time trajectories and potential interpretations such as happiness or well-being.
